nodes.text: Probability weighting (inverse-S between decision weights w(x) and declared probabilities p(x)) can be mechanistically explained as decision makers having greater uncertainty than disinterested observers because they estimate probabilities from finite time series

Empirical observation: cumulative decision weights Fw plotted versus cumulative probabilities Fp produce a robust inverse-S curve (Fw > Fp for low cumulative probabilities, Fw < Fp for high cumulative probabilities)

Definitions: p(x) denotes probabilities specified by a disinterested observer (DO); w(x) denotes decision weights inferred from a decision maker's (DM) behavior; CDFs Fp and Fw defined by integrating p and w

Claim: If the DM's model uses a larger scale or different location than the DO's model (e.g., Gaussians with same mean but DM std dev = alpha * DO std dev, alpha>1), the mapping Fw versus Fp generically yields an inverse-S
Claim: Estimating probabilities from finite time series produces uncertainties whose relative size grows as event probability decreases, so rare events have larger relative estimation error
Method: General numerical procedure to produce mapping: compute DO CDF Fp(x), compute DM CDF Fw(x) (from assumed distribution), and plot Fw(x) against Fp(x) to visualise probability weighting

Result (analytic): For Gaussian DO with std sigma and DM with std alpha*sigma, eliminating x yields decision weight w as a power-law function of p with exponent 1/alpha^2, producing w(p)>p for small p when alpha>1

Evidence (simulation): Simulations where DM counts events in finite series and adds standard error produce inverse-S mappings for both Gaussian and fat-tailed t distributions; effect stronger for fat tails

Result (fit): Gaussian and t-models derived from the mechanistic explanation fit experimental inverse-S data (Tversky & Kahneman 1992; Tversky & Fox 1995) as well as established phenomenological parameterisations

Assumption: DO and DM have different observational perspectives and objectives (DO often uses ensemble perspective; DM experiences single trajectory over time), leading to different optimal models when observables are non-ergodic

Method/Claim: A conservative DM can form decision weights by adding the standard error of the estimated density to the estimate and normalising (w(x) proportional to p_hat(x)+epsilon[p_hat(x)]), producing systematic overweighting of rare events

Conclusion: Probability weighting (inverse-S) need not imply DM cognitive bias; it can be a principled, rational response to greater uncertainty faced by a DM estimating probabilities from finite time series and to time vs ensemble perspective

Limitation: Mechanistic model relies on assumptions about how DMs estimate probabilities (finite sample counts, bin width T delta x, addition of standard error) and on specific distributional forms when fitting; results depend on these choices
